coredata.dc:title: Range of the screened coulomb interaction in electrolytes and double layer problems
coredata.dc:creator: John Mitchell, D.
Ninham, Barry W.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
It is shown that the range of the Coulomb interaction in unsymmetric electrolytes at large distances is determined not by the Debye screening length, but by a rather more complicated function of the density, which is evaluated explicitly.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 53, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 January 1978 RANGE OF THE SCREENED COULOMB INTERACTION DM ELECTROLYTES AND DOUBLE LAYER PROBLEMS D. John MITCHELL and Barry W. NINHAM Department of Applied Mathematics. Research School of Physical Sciences. Institute of Advanced Studies, The Australian National University, Canberra. A.C.T. 2600, Australia Received 10 June 1977 Revised manuscript received 23 November 1977 K is shown that the range of the Coulomb interaction in unsymmetric electrolytes at large distances is determined not by the Debye screening length, but by a rather more complicated function of the density, which is evaluated explicitly. In a not very recent calculation [1,2] the authors derived the asymptotic form of the pair distribution function of a classical electron gas. We have extended that result to the primitive model of electrolytes. For the one-component electron gas Gellium model) the pair distribution function has the asymptotic form [2] g^fr) l-(Afx)e-BX (1) X- where ifA=(47r<3^p) 'is the dimensionless plasma parameter (A is denoted by e in ref. [2]); KQ1 = (4lTJ3^2p)l/2 is the Debye screening length; andx= icyr; r = [r^ — r-^ |, A and B have the explicit asymptotic expansions A=A+(|l^3-^|^)A2+b(A3l^A), (2) B = 1 + iA In 3 + A2^ In A + 0.66) + 0(A3 In A). (3) Here q is the unit charge, 0 = IfkT, and p is the elec- tron density. This result follows from the Montroll— Mayer cluster expansion method. The first terms ofeq. (3) are already implicit in the hypemetted chain ap- proximation which neglects so-called bridge, or non- elementary diagrams, although this is not generally rec- ognised because most solutions for the primitive mod- el of electrolytes are numerical, and deal with. thermo- dynamic properties only. We have extended eq. (1) to a two-component elec- trolyte. The argument very closely parallels the treat- meat in ref- [2] and we simply summarise the neces- sary steps. Consider a solution of a strong electrolyte C^1 AJ2 in an aqueous solvent of dielectric constant e at density p molecules/cm3. (7) then yields gy-OO^e-^/Jc, (15) where 0»i z? + ^I)2 5=H-iAln3————————+0(A31nA). (16) (v^i+v^y- The correction term to the Debye screening length vanishes identically for symmetric electrolytes. It is obvious that the mean spherical model cannot give out the correct asymptotic form for the pair distribution function and therefore it is no surprise that the mean spherical model is inadequate especially for unsym- metric electrolytes. To obtain ah estimate of the region of validity of eq. (16), it is sufficient to note from eq. (3) that the ratio of the third to second terms is ^ A = HQfSq^le. The result also breaks down when KQR{. becomes sig- nificant compared with unity. At room temperature (SQ2fe ^ 7 A, so that the necessary condition (KQRf.)2 <^ 1 is always satisfied for real electrolytes whenever A < 1. For unsymmetric electrolytes we have from eq. (16) - (17) where c is the salt concentration in moles per litre, and we have explicitly K(eff) "0 (18) {lO~2M 1.06(2:1) 1.12(2:3) 1.32(3:1) lO^M 1-18 (2 : 1) 1.39 (2:3) 2 (3 : 1) At 10~1 M the effective screening length formula has certainly broken down. The result eq. (17) has clear implications for double layer problems and questions of colloid stability where the long range nature of the screened Coulomb interaction is important. Recently Israelachvili and Adams [3] have meas- ured double layer forces operating between molec- ularly smooth mica surfaces in various aqueous elec- trolyte solutions. For 1 : 1 electrolytes the screening length agrees with the theoretical KQ within experi- mental error up to lO^ molar in agreement with ex- pectation. On the other hand, for 2:1 electrolytes, the screening length deviates by 20% at l0~4 M and by 40% at 10~3 M from KQ in the direction indicated by eq. (18). The density expansion for K (efi) is clearly 398 Volume 53, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 January 1978 of limited validity, and e.g. a variational approach to References the hypemetted chain equation might be expected to do better. head.ce:title: Range of the screened coulomb interaction in electrolytes and double layer problems

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Applied Mathematics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Institute of Advanced Studies, The Australian National University, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600, Australia

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: It is shown that the range of the Coulomb interaction in unsymmetric electrolytes at large distances is determined not by the Debye screening length, but by a rather more complicated function of the density, which is evaluated explicitly.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: J.N. Israelachvilli and G.E. Adams, J. Chem. Soc. Faraday II, to be published.
